discussion.content:
Correct answer is C.
Cat6 only supports 10 Gbp/s to 165 feet (55 meters).
Cat6A supports 10 Gbp/s (Gigabits per second) up to 328 feet (100 meters). 
More info : https://www.truecable.com/blogs/cable-academy/cat6-vs-cat6a
Could Cat7 also be an option here as it also supports 10Gbp/s at 100 meters?

comments.content: Cat7 is more expensive and the issue says we have to minimize costs.

questions.question_text: A network technician has purchased a 10GBase-T switch and wishes to connect it to 30 computers with 10GB network cards. The computers are 225ft (69m) away, and all need to establish a 10 Gbps connection to meet business requirements. To minimize costs while still meeting these requirements, which of the following cable types should the technician choose?

choices.C: Reverse the wires leading to pins 2 and 3
choices.D: Reverse the wires leading to pins 2 and 4
choices.A: Reverse the wires leading to pins 1 and 2
choices.B: Reverse the wires leading to pins 1 and 3

discussion.content: How is this possible?You should reverse 1 with 3 and 2 with 6.
Remember, this is an OLDER PC, so we'll assume 10/100, not gig. Only four wires used out of eight.
Another question that is is beyond the scope of any material I have studied. I'm currently looking through my text book and viewing Professor Messer's notes and I don't see how the answer could be D.

This question is weird because of the "older PC" part, so only 4 pins should be used. However, for traditional Crossover Cable for memorization, I think of these rules:
1) reverse 1/3
2) reverse 2&6
3) -3 brown (pin 7 -> pin 4 / pin 8 -> pin 5)
4) +3 blue (pin 4 -> pin 7 / pin 5 -> pin 8)
Or
T568A -> T568B

Answer is - B
https://armantutorial.files.wordpress.com/2015/01/rj45-diagram.jpg

The correct answer is B. This is just half work to do for reverse a cable.
1----->3 and 2---->6

comments.content: If you're changing pins 1 and 2 wouldn't that be A as the right answer and not B?

discussion.content:
B is the correct answer.
To connect two computers it is needful to use a crossover cable.
https://helpdeskgeek.com/networking/connect-two-computers-using-a-crossover-cable/
B is the right answer.

Cross-checking this question on other places confirms the answer is D when that clearly isn't the case. Is there even any guarantee that this question shows up on the exam when the answer listed here is not right?
I was looking at other websites as well. This should be 1 and 3. Pin 4, 5, 7 , and 8 does not change.
Great... So no one was able to find an explanation for this.
Quizlet says B
The correct answer is pin 1,2,3,6 should be reverse which is not in the multiple choice answers
B should be the correct answer as pin 4 5 7 8 won't change, either pin 1&3 or 2&6.

The answer to this question should be "B". Like radu and TT pointed out, to make a crossover cable you need to reverse the wires going to pin 1 and pin 3, and then reverse the wires going to pin 2 and pin 6. Since "B" is the only answer that matches one of these steps it should be "B".
On second thought, the answer should be A. It asks which pins you REVERSE. You have to reverse pin 1 so that it connects to pinout 3 and pin 2 so that it connects to pinout 6.
This is wrong. Pins 4, 5, 7, and 8 never change. I think the answer should be B

questions.question_text: A technician is setting up a direct connection between two older PCs so they can communicate but not be on the corporate network. The technician does not have access to a spare switch but does have spare Cat 6 cables, RJ-45 plugs, and a crimping tool. The technician cuts off one end of the cable. Which of the following should the technician do to make a crossover cable before crimping the new plug?

discussion.content:
A mail exchanger record (MX record) is a DNS record that specifies the mail server responsible for accepting email messages on behalf of a domain name
A Canonical Name record (abbreviated as CNAME record) is a DNS record that maps one domain name (an alias) to another (the canonical name)
AAAA records are DNS records that use an IP address to connect a domain to a website, and deal with IPv6 addresses
The DNS "service" (SRV) record specifies a host and port for specific services such as voice over IP (VoIP), instant messaging, and so on.

questions.question_text: A technician is configuring a new email server and needs to modify DNS records. Which of the following records should the technician update to ensure email functions as expected?

choices.A: BPDUs entering the root bridge are ignored.
choices.D: Loop protection is enabled on the root port of a switch.
choices.C: Broadcast storms entering from a root port are blocked.
choices.B: The STP root bridge cannot be changed.

discussion.content:
B seems to be correct. 
after https://www.rogerperkin.co.uk/spanning-tree/spanning-tree-root-guard/

"Unlike the BPDU Guard which will disable a port upon receipt of a BPDU, the Spanning Tree Root Guard feature will allow BPDU’s through a port to maintain the spanning tree topology, however if it receives a superior BPDU, which indicates that another switch is trying to become the root bridge it will err-disable the port.

This feature is used to protect your root bridges from misconfiguration or a layer 2 man in the middle attack."

BPDU Guard: Prevents accidental connection of switching devices to PortFast-enabled ports. Connecting switches to PortFast-enabled ports can cause Layer 2 loops or topology changes.

BPDU filtering: Restricts the switch from sending unnecessary BPDUs out access ports.

Root Guard: Prevents switches connected on ports configured as access ports from becoming
the root switch.

The correct answer is B. The STP root bridge cannot be changed.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst3560/software/release/12-2_52_se/configuration/guide/3560scg/swstpopt.html#wp1031307
B is correct - BPDU Guard is in place to protect STP hierarchy and root bridge
Answer A should be the better one. Refer to Network+ Student Guide, Lesson 3: Installing and Configuring Switched Networks | Topic B | Page 82

questions.question_text: Which of the following BEST describes the functionality of the root guard feature on a switch?
A network administrator is adding a new WAN circuit from the ISP to a new building. In which of the following locations would the network administrator find the utility entry point?

discussion.content: The wording of this question is terrible. Demarc is a device where the ISP's network ends and the organization's network begins. A location would be an IDF or MDF, not Demarc. MDF's usually contain the Demarc, but not always.
